instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3330: What is 820-3330? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.A1286: What is A1286? A1286 is a model number for a 15 inch size MacBook Pro Unibody from years Late 2008, Mid 2009, Mid 2009 , Mid 2010, Early 2011, Late 2011, Mid 2012 with EMC 2255, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-2330, 820-2532, 820-2523, 820-2533, 820-2850, 820-2915, 820-3330..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Killing SATA Cables?
threads.message:
I can't edit the title, but I got this board mixed up with another one (very similar). This is also an <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> board.

Symptoms:

1. Board won't detect hard drive; doesn't show in EFI, and flashing folder appears.
2. Drive gets power; I can hear the whine of the drive being powered, but no "ticking" (data). When I disconnect power, I can hear the typical click-off of drive.
3. Pin 7 of <CHIP>U4510</CHIP> is 3.3v
4. <CAPACITOR>C4510</CAPACITOR> and <CAPACITOR>C4511</CAPACITOR> both look like they've seen significant heat/draw (not shorted, but darker-yellow on the end caps than others)
5. Board boots to USB drive fine; WiFi, BT, Audio, etc., all work.
6. Drive not detected in disk utility or System Info, of course.
7. All resistors measure out fine around <CHIP>U4800</CHIP>/<CHIP>U4510</CHIP>, etc.

So I suspect some issue with the data connection. I replaced <CHIP>U4510</CHIP>, <CAPACITOR>C4510</CAPACITOR> and <CAPACITOR>C4511</CAPACITOR>, but no dice. There are lots of data lines related to J4501, so unsure which others I should be looking at.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Killing SATA Cables?
threads.message: 3115 I assume. Did you try a known good HDD cable? Don't fold them too sharply as they will be dead again.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Killing SATA Cables?
threads.message:
Hey Duke. This is still an <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>, apologies for confusion. Tried tons of known-good cables, no dice. Also tried 3 other boards in the same casing and all work well/fine.

Could it be a PCH issue? No liquid, but maybe a drop? I've seen a few dropped boards that had very particular/singular issues like this...most commonly, missing data/clock signals to LCD.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Killing SATA Cables?
threads.message: Checked <CAPACITOR>C4510</CAPACITOR>,11,15,16? Checked continuity from HDD connector SATA lines to those caps? Only 4 data lines involved in this.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Killing SATA Cables?
threads.message:
Hey Duke, thanks. I just re-checked all those things; continuity between all caps & J4501; continuity from <CHIP>U4510</CHIP> to <CAPACITOR>C4517</CAPACITOR>/18. All checks out.

I checked at <CAPACITOR>C4517</CAPACITOR>/18 pins 1 with an oscilloscope, and on a good board, it's a nice healthy signal. On this bad board, nothing (drive connected, etc). I might give up on this one, thinking maybe a PCH issue. If you have anything else I should check I will. Thanks so much for the help! This one kicked my ass.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Killing SATA Cables?
threads.message:
bit this is <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1286</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>, the only one laptop in entire history which kills SATA cables.

the exact reason is that when you install HDD it pushes flex cable hard enough to get a short to ground. since fuses never really blow in MacBooks, cable dies.
simply put some insulator tape under the cable in HDD cage and install a new cable. However, maybe it was one of the rare moments some fuse was actually blown by a short circuit.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Killing SATA Cables?
threads.message: Thanks for the reply, but that's not the case here. This is certainly a board issue, thanks. We've replaced hundreds of cables due to the known-issue with them. This is definitely not a cable issue.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Killing SATA Cables?
threads.message: If it is a PCH issue chances are good that the DVD is also not recognized, did you check that? If DVD works just put a HDD caddy there and boot from there.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Killing SATA Cables?
threads.message: Damn, good idea. Thanks, Duke. I'll check that today--interesting.
